name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-Nitrophenyl)-2-furyl]-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1190

name: (2E)-3-[5-(4-Nitrophenyl)-2-furyl]-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1190
Reason:
To predict the melting point for the compound (2E)-3-[5-(4-Nitrophenyl)-2-furyl]-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one, we can start by considering benzene as the basic unit, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The introduction of various functional groups will alter this value. Here is how each functional group can be expected to affect the melting point: 
- Phenyl groups: +20°C each (aromaticity increases intermolecular forces). The target compound has two phenyl groups. 
- Furanyl ring: +30°C (contributes to the rigidity and planarity of the molecule, which can increase melting point). 
- Nitro group: +50°C (strong electron-withdrawing group that can significantly increase intermolecular forces). 
- Alpha, beta-unsaturated carbonyl group (enone): +40°C (polarity and possibility of hydrogen bonding). 
- Combining these adjustments, we get an increase of 160°C from the base benzene value.
